awd_titl_txt: AiTF: Collaborative Research: Distributed and Stochastic Algorithms for Active Matter: Theory and Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
Swarm robotics explores how groups of robots can work towards a singular goal, which is typically achieved by equipping each robot with sensory capabilities, basic computing power, and movement. The sensors detect and use information about the environment to decide on the next action. Swarm robotics has made many advances in recent years, but is still in its infancy. This project proposes to explore swarm robotics systems in a non-standard way as  physical systems. The PIs take a "task-oriented" approach to develop the distributed algorithmic rules that the robots will run (at the microscopic level) in order to converge to the desired collective behavior (at the macroscopic level).  This will provide understanding of the minimal requirements for individuals to accomplish the desired behavior, for both algorithmic and physical realizations, and will provide a more principled approach for studying swarm robotics. The robots envisioned are small in scale, ranging in size from millimeters to centimeters, so that when deployed in dense environments, they will behave as programmable active matter.

The PIs have strong records for interdisciplinary research, including initiating interdisciplinary areas (e.g., robo-physics, self-organizing particle systems, and the fusion of statistical physics and randomized algorithms). They have a strong commitment toward supporting minorities, women, and undergrad research (e.g., through NSF REUs, including through this project, NSF S-STEM programs at ASU; ADVANCE and S.U.R.E. programs at Georgia Tech).  Any breakthrough in this combination of swarm and active matter systems will require employing analyses and techniques from stochastic systems, condensed matter physics, swarm systems, robotics, and distributed algorithms to understand and achieve the desired group dynamics, and hence will bring together and educate researchers from different disciplines and specialties.  New research approaches and findings will be incorporated into multiple graduate courses and workshops will provide tutorials for bridging multiple disciplines, making material accessible to young researchers and helping to widely disseminate results. Findings (including open source code) will be published in the various disciplines, and will be be made available on our web pages and ArXiv.   
 
The project explores the fundamentals of swarm robotics from a physics standpoint, by viewing the ensemble as active matter composed of programmable elements at the micro-level.  The project will follow a (macro-)task oriented approach, and design a distributed stochastic algorithmic framework to design and evaluate algorithms at the micro-level that will yield the targeted emergent macroscopic behavior.  The emergent behaviors it addresses include compression (maintaining coherence of a connected community while minimizing perimeter), bridging (connecting two or more locations in the most efficient manner), alignment (determining an agreed upon direction of orientation), jamming (obstruction of movement by increased collective flow), and locomotion (collectively moving while maintaining cohesiveness). Many of these have interesting converse problems which are also equally worthwhile, such as exploration (maintaining a connected population, but exploring maximal area) and non-alignment (representing a disordered ensemble). In some cases the collective behavior acts like a physical system changing between a liquid (disordered) and a solid (ordered) state, as determined by phase transitions in the systems. The project will explore stochastic and distributed algorithms for rigorously achieving these goals.

por.por_cntn:
Swarm robotics explores how groups of robots can work towards a singular goal. Such a goal is typically achieved by equipping each robot with some sensory capabilities, basic computing power, and actuation. The sensors detect something about the environment, this information is used to make a decision about the next action, and some resulting actuation is performed. Swarm robotics has made many advances in recent years, but it is still in its infancy.

In this project, we explored swarm robotics systems in a non-standard way, by establishing close analogies to physical systems. We took a "task-oriented" approach, starting from a desired macroscopic emergent collective behavior to develop the distributed and stochastic algorithmic underpinnings that the robots need to run (at the microscopic level) in order to converge to the desired macroscopic behavior; as part of the process, we also provide the understanding for yet unexplored collective and emergent systems. The envisioned robots are small in scale, ranging in size from millimeters to centimeters, so that when deployed in crowded (i.e., dense) environments, they behave as active matter, more specifically as macroscopic programmable active matter.

The emergent behaviors we simulated include

- compression (maintaining coherence of a connected community while minimizing perimeter), and aggregation (similar to compression but where the system may disconnect in the process) [Science Advances'21; SSS'21],

- task clearing (when aggregated, the collective can transport non-robot "impurities") [Science Advances'21],

- (species) separation or segregation (forming tight-knit communities of different species that are each mostly well-connected) [RANDOM-APPROX'19],

- shortcut bridging (when collections of agents -- or "ants" -- bridge gaps and shortcut their path from base to "food") [Natural Computing'18],

- foraging (where "ants" alternate between searching for "food" and gathering around some found "food" until it is depleted) [in submission],

- flocking (determining an agreed upon direction of orientation) [in submission], and

- locomotion (collectively moving while maintaining cohesiveness) [Artificial Life and Robotics'18].

Many of these have interesting converse problems which we also explored, such as  exploration (maintaining a connected population, but exploring maximal area), dispersion (exploring maximal area while allowing the system to disconnect), and desegregation (preventing species separation in a mixture of particles). We also explored novel algorithms for other basic problems that arise in self-organizing swarm collectives, such as energy distribution and management [ICDCN'21], and finding shortest enclosures [ICDCN'20]. We developed stochastic and distributed algorithms for rigorously achieving these goals. 

This theoretical framework for task-oriented active matter was informed by our building simple physical systems that can realize and test these algorithms. In particular, PI Goldman's lab developed two swarm robotics platforms, the BoBBots and the smarticles, that were built to mimic some of the main characteristics of physical systems encountered in nature, with limited to no computational power and memory, moderate attraction or entanglement properties, rudimentary individual locomotion capabilities, etc. This allowed the refinement of our theories based on unexpected constraints, such as effects of gravity or limited energy. It also allowed us to test our algorithms for robustness, as the physical systems admit some error.

Intellectual Merit:

This project explored the fundamentals of swarm robotics from a physics standpoint, by viewing the ensemble as active matter composed of programmable elements at the micro-level. We followed a (macro-)task oriented approach, and designed a distributed and stochastic algorithmic framework to design and evaluate algorithms at the micro-level that yields the targeted emergent macroscopic behavior of the system. To enable such a breakthrough that combines swarm and active matter systems, we employed analyses and techniques from stochastic systems, condensed matter physics, swarm systems, robotics, and distributed algorithms to understand and achieve the desired group dynamics, and hence to bring together researchers from different disciplines and specialties. The challenges we addressed have solid grounding on existing physical collectives (rather than on abstract systems). One of our main contributions was to add rigorous algorithmic analysis to the field of active matter.

Broader Impact:

The PIs have strong records for interdisciplinary research, including initiating interdisciplinary areas (e.g., robophysics by PI Goldman, the study of self-organizing particle systems by Richa, and the fusion of statistical physics and randomized CS processes by Randall). They also have strong commitment toward supporting minorities, women, and undergrad research: Richa supported minorities at ASU through six NSF SSTEM scholarship grants, and has a high record of female advisees and undergrad research mentoring; Randall is the ADVANCE Professor of Computing at Georgia Tech and actively participates in internal and external programs to promote women; Goldman has worked with S.U.R.E. minority undergraduates for eight years. This project brought together techniques from multiple disciplines, and new research approaches and findings that were incorporated into the PIs' graduate courses. Findings were published in the various disciplines, and also made available on the PIs' webpages and through ArXiv, and all code is open source and made available on webpages.
